newsitem.title: UK: German soccer team rallies behind English anthem.
newsitem.headline: German soccer team rallies behind English anthem.

text.p: The Germans may have beaten England in last year's European championship, but when they wanted a soccer anthem for the nation to rally behind, they turned to an Englishman, writing in English.
Composer Mike Batt admitted being somewhat baffled when he was approached by the Germans.
"I was very surprised to find myself writing the anthem for England's main opponents," the prolific songwriter told the Daily Telegraph on Tuesday.
"The idea felt uncomfortable for about five minutes but goals win matches, not anthems."
Batt, whose hits include the chart-topping Bright Eyes and a string of successes for 1970s pop group The Wombles, was commissioned to write the song after a chat with German team manager Berti Vogts.
"At the end of the meeting he said: 'Oh, sorry for winning the European championship'," Batt told the Guardian.
Germany beat England on penalties in the semi-final -- as they did in the 1990 World Cup in Italy -- before taking the title with a 2-1 win over the Czech Republic.
Batt will conduct the anthem, entitled Running With a Dream, in front of 13 million television viewers on September 6 before Germany play Romania.
The English words should not pose too much of a problem. "The German pop (music) charts are full of English-speaking artists," he said.
